results.title: Pearl Harbour December 7th
results.brief_description: A few cameras were on hand to record the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbour on December 7th 1941, film director John Ford’s unit was given the task of recreating many of the major scenes on Hollywood sound stages. Generations of Americans have witnessed the scenes, not realising the attack is actually Ford’s skilful illusion. Historically, the film is accurate in every detail. Winner of the Academy Award for Documentary Production in 1943.

results.title: Pearl Harbor = Pearl Harbour
results.creator_credit: Jerry Bruckheimer Films, Jerry Bruckheimer and Michael Bay
results.brief_description: Resoundingly derided drama about the invasion on Pearl Harbor by the Japanese, this film, directed by Michael Bay, nonetheless contains some impressive sequences, mostly the expertly executed and detailed battle scenes. Less engaging is the love triangle between two pilots, and the girl they both fall for. Cast includes Ben Affleck, Josh Hartnett, Kate Beckinsale, Cuba Gooding Jnr, Jon Voight.

results.title: Peaches, pears and people
results.brief_description: Looks at the peach and pear industry in the Shepparton district, Victoria - from the initial cultivation of the crops to the final stages of production in the factory.

results.title: Peach and pear harvester
results.brief_description: Picture only. Footage of specialised machine used for quickly removing fruit from peach and pair trees. The machine envelopes a tree and then vibrates which causes the fruit to fall off into a catching device. This is an odd process to view as the tree is shaken quite violently by the machine and the fruit falls into the catching device in a dramamtic fashion.

results.title: Peach's gold
results.brief_description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. Through dramatised re-enactments and historical footage, the effects of the new economic force on population, the location of towns, wealth generation, the development of transport networks and the introduction of a representative democracy are all investigated. In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.
results.description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. Through dramatised re-enactments and historical footage, the effects of the new economic force on population, the location of towns, wealth generation, the development of transport networks and the introduction of a representative democracy are all investigated. In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.

In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.

results.title: Peach's Australia: Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, David Roberts and Bill Peach
results.brief_description:
Popular former ABC TV personality Bill Peach travels the length and breadth of Australia seeking out often little known facets of the country’s history and their relation to present day conditions in the particular areas.
In this episode, Bill Peach explores Arnhem Land and it’s history, as seen by the Aboriginal people who live there. The program was filmed at the Gove, Elcho Island, Deaf Adder Gorge, Murganella and other places within the Kakadu National Park and includes a visit to the oldest rock paintings in Australia.

results.title: Peach's Australia : The Dandenongs
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
The Dandenong’s are the lungs of Melbourne, and an enchanting weekend tourist resort with rare plant and animal life. Its charm is now being eroded by urban sprawl

results.title: Peach's Australia : Murray Riverboats
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Lloyd Capps
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
The Murray River has many problems, including pollution, the dwindling of its native fish, and the introduction of the European Carp, but the biggest problem has been in the threatened loss of its history. To Bill Peach, “the riverboats represent the most colourful and romantic part of that history, and the skeletons of riverboats are symbols of our failure to love and care for our greatest river. Written and presented by Bill Peach.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Mount Buffalo
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Lloyd Capps
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
It is the position of Mt Buffalo, standing apart from the Victorian Alps, and its extraordinary shape, that have led it to being called Australia’s grandest, wildest, most novel and most romantic mountain.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Hahndorf
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Alan Bateman and Bill Steller
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
Traces the history of the town of Hahndorf, South Australia, beginning with the German settlers who arrived at Port Misery (Port Adelaide) in 1838. Outlines their reasons for leaving Germany, the establishment of Klemzig, the movement of some Germans into the Adelaide Hills and the difficulties they encountered. Suitable for upper secondary level.
